718737f-a.text:
Cherry Street (left), south side, east from Clinton to and including Montgomery Streets, showing the Seventh Ward Athletic Field extending south to Water Street, the buildings shown on the right, across the
athletic field, are facing on Water Street.
March 22, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
718737f-a.folder: Cherry Street & Clinton Street, Manhattan, NY

719007f-a.text:
Clinton Street, west side, north from and including Cherry Street. Also shown (left) is No. 314 Cherry, at the N.W. corner of Clinton Streets, and bearing also No. 251 on the latter street.
March 22, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
719007f-a.folder: Clinton Street & Cherry Street, Manhattan, NY

718734f-b.text:
(1)
323-325 (2-story structure), and 327 to 333 Cherry Street, south
side between Clinton and Montgomery Streets. The four 2-1/2-story houses
(Nos. 327 to 333) are at this date approximately 100 years old and
were, during the last century, part of the fashionable Cherry Hill
residential district. This area is now part of New York's worst slum
district.
March 23, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, viewed reversely (westward), and showing part of the
Seventh Ward Athletic Field, extending to Clinton Street.
March 22, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A similar view to No. 1, being photographed in an eastward
direction, showing the vacant site where the former 2 and 2-1/2-story
buildings stood.
Thru this clearance appears a modern factory structure on
Water Street. At the left margin is Montgomery Street.
April 23, 1939.
P. L. Sperr.
718734f-b.folder: Cherry Street & Clinton Street, Manhattan, NY

718736f-b.text:
Cherry Street, east from Clinton Street, showing tenements on the north side facing the Seventh Ward Athletic Field. At this date, this is being used for storage purposes. The factory
seen at the rignt margin is No. 5Bl Water Street.
View No. 3 is phoographed from this vantage point in a nor thward direction, to show Cherry Street buildings bearing No's. 326 to 336 (vacant lot at right) Facing these ahd obstrtucting them from view from this point, ware four,2Astory old structures (No's 327-to 333 Cherry Street) that have re3ently been rased.
April 23, 1939
Views: 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr
718736f-b.folder: Cherry Street & Clinton Street, Manhattan, NY

718735f-b.text:
Cherry Street, north side, west from but not including Clinton Street.
Note the clearance (center of view) created by the demolition of four
5-story buildings, Nos. 302 to 296.
March 22, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #2656
The New York Times of July 15, 1938, reports the proposed demolition
of No. 304 Cherry Street, which is the first 5 story tenement this side
of the clearance.
(2) and (3)
Neg. #2657
The same area as No. 1, subsequent to the noted demolition
(Vacant space in center) and during a similar project at the N.W.
corner. View 3 emphasizes this last mentioned phase and includes
a perspective along Clinton Street (right), across Monroe and
Madison Streets respectively.
June 23, 1939
718735f-b.folder: Cherry Street & Clinton Street, Manhattan, NY

719008f-a.text:
250 to 244 Clinton Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Cherry Street. The view is across a clearance at the N.W. corner sid is in an eastward
direction.
August 2, 1939
L. Sperr
